quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: that the foreman had seen in Bindle the means of his obtaining some sleep and arriving at his bean-feast refreshed.  At eleven o'clock he left the hotel, after having given to his deputy the most elaborate instructions.
title: Bindle: Some Chapters in the Life of Joseph Bindle
author: Jenkins, Herbert George, 1876-1923

quoteTime: About nine o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , the clouds began to gather, and we had a prodigious fall of rain, with severe thunder and lightning. By midnight we had caught about twenty gallons of water.
title: A narrative of the mutiny, on board His Majesty's ship Bounty
author: Bligh, William, 1754-1817

quoteFirst: When we rode through the last clumps and reached the prairie on the other side of the wood, the sunbeams were falling on it obliquely, and we did not miss the delightful shade so much as we should have done had we exposed ourselves to the sun a few hours earlier. We rode sharply, and at
title: The Backwoodsman; Or, Life on the Indian Frontier
author: Wraxall, Lascelles, Sir, 1828-1865 [Editor]

quoteFirst: I called Eddrees, gave him ten rounds of ball cartridge for each of his men, and told him to keep with my party should we be obliged to march: he immediately called a number of natives and concealed all his ivory in the jungle. At
quoteLast: the camp was in an uproar; suddenly drums beat in all quarters, in reply to nogaras that sounded the alarm in Kamrasi's camp; horns bellowed; men and women yelled; huts were set on fire; and in the blaze of light hundreds of natives, all armed and dressed for war, rushed frantically about, as usual upon such occasions, gesticulating, and engaging in mock fight with each other, as though full of valour and boiling over with a desire to meet the enemy.
title: The Albert N'Yanza, Great Basin of the Nile, And Explorations of the Nile Sources
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteFirst: Accordingly, having arranged with Alice to send the close carriage for her on the day but one following, he took leave of the Hazlehurst family, and drove to H--------. Here, after a long examination, the aforesaid poachers were convicted, and sentenced,
quoteLast: months’, another to a year’s imprisonment--Markum’s evidence being so clear and convincing, that such an issue became inevitable. As the gamekeeper left the court, a tall, gipsy-looking fellow came up to him, and muttered in his car, “You’ll live to repent this day’s work, Master Keeper; look to yourself one of these dark nights.
title: Harry Coverdale's Courtship, and All That Came of It
author: Smedley, Frank E. (Frank Edward), 1818-1864

quoteFirst: repair daily, supplies to remove from godowns which were fallen in from the effects of the enemy's shot, mines to countermine, guns to remove, barricades to erect, corpses to bury, and rations to serve out; but with our weak, harassed, and daily diminishing garrison, we could seldom produce as working parties more than three fatigue parties of eight or ten men each relief; and the Europeans were capable of but little exertion, as from want of sleep, hard work night and day, and constant exposure, their bodily strength was greatly diminished. The enemy threw in an 8-inch shell
quoteLast: and fired all the evening. Divine service was performed at the brigade-mess in the morning, and in the afternoon, at Dr. Fayrer's; the sacrament was administered on both occasions.
title:
The Defence of Lucknow
A Diary Recording the Daily Events during the Siege of the European Residency, from 31st May to 25th September, 1857
author: Wilson, T. F. (Thomas Fourness)

quoteFirst: On the 29th of July, 1835, Kasper Boeck, a shepherd of the little village of Hirschwiller, with his large felt hat tipped back, his wallet of stringy sackcloth hanging at his hip, and his great tawny dog at his heels, presented himself at
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: at the house of the burgomaster, Petrus Mauerer, who had just finished supper and was taking a little glass of kirchwasser to facilitate digestion.
title: Library of the World's Best Mystery and Detective Stories

quoteFirst: The changes of temperature from winter to summer are rapid, owing to the great increase in the length of the day. In May the sun rises at about 3 a.m. and sets
quoteLast: In June it rises about 1:30 in the morning and sets at 10:30 p.m., giving about twenty hours of daylight, and diffuse twilight the remainder of the time.
title:
Along Alaska's Great River

quoteFirst: We crossed the Equator in glorious weather
quoteLast: on Monday, June 9th. None of the forecastle had been over before: Father Neptune did not feel equal to visiting them, but some addition to the fare was much appreciated.
title: The mystery of Easter island: the story of an expedition
